body:
This option can be used to enable treesitter features for a given buffer / globally.

For now the bare minimum is done, and is still very wip.

The roadmap is the following :
- [X] Create option
- [X] Setup highlighting when `set treesitter=hl` is done
- [ ] Remove highlighting when `set treesitter=` is done

comment_data.body: as an option, I would probably expect `treesitter` to not influence `syntax`. But it currently does, maybe this could be change within this PR. So you can have `treesitter=hl`/`syntax=on` or `treesitter=hl`/`syntax=off`, but with syntax only explicitly changing. Alternative `syntax=off,on,treesitter` is probably confusing.

comment_data.body:
Related:

* https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/16008#issuecomment-945235165
* https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15260#issuecomment-945235576
* In https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/15585 we used `vim.diagnostic.config` for diagnostics options.
    * Ideally, "vim options" are probably the Right Way. So +1 for this 'treesitter' option.

I think allowing both is the right way since `:syntax` does provide a simple way of extending syntax highlighting. For example I use it for a bunch of niche filetypes where I want to highlight something specific to a project. I could migrate these to use TS queries, but why bother.

still, `:set treesitter=hl` should not cause `syntax=off`. Both should be changed independently from each other

comment_regular_data.body: Is this something we want to revisit? Or is it superseded by nvim-treesitter's module system (i.e., this is the approach that should eventually come into core, when stable)?
I personally prefer this approach, because it might be more useful when customizing how the tree-sitter C interface is used.

We should revisit this as part of the "Lua highlighting in core" goal for 0.8.

(scope should be buffer-local, though?)

> We should revisit this as part of the "Lua highlighting in core" goal for 0.8.
> 
> (scope should be buffer-local, though?)

It can only be buffer-local since extmarks are buffer local.

An alternative would be to mirror the `vim.lsp.start({...})` pattern, where the table could contain options like whether regex syntax is still run, the location of the parser and the queries, etc. (with reasonable defaults) that people can put in a manual `FileType` autocommand for 0.8.

(Later, we can set these up automatically.)
